intro: Anethum pinnatum, commonly known as the Indian cumin or wild cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Indian subcontinent. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley, dill, and carrots, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30 to 60 centimeters and has finely divided, feathery leaves. Its seeds, which are used in culinary and medicinal applications, are small, oblong, and have a distinct, pungent aroma. Anethum pinnatum thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, open habitats.
